PAL.NAME: Microsoft Office SharePoint Server (MOSS) 2007 and Search
PAL.DESCRIPTION: MOSS Search(Crawling) and quick general operating system performance analysis. Use this for analysis of MOSS Search and high level OS analysis. This threshold file does not contain the Process object to help reduce overhead.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Total Docs in First Queue (Portal_Content)
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \Office Server Search Archival Plugin(Portal_Content)\Total docs in first queue
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
This counter shows how many entries the crawler has queued waiting to write to the SSP search database. This analysis checks to see if the number of documents in the first and second queues are too high. If the value here stays at 500 for Portal Content, or 50 for ProfileImport, for any period of time, the crawler is being starved by time spent in the archival plugin, which likely indicates SQL I/O issues. Peaks to this number are allowable under brief times of heavy load. Sustained periods at the maximum values are a cause for concern. Improving SQL I/O latency on this database with help fix this issue. Consider splitting the SSP search database into two file groups, via the supported method provided by Microsoft. SQL File groups and Search

For more on understanding the crawler counters and performance, please read the following: Creating crawl schedules and starvation - How to detect it and minimize it

DATASOURCE.NAME: \Office Server Search Archival Plugin(Portal_Content)\Total docs in first queue
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \Office Server Search Archival Plugin(Portal_Content)\Total docs in first queue

THRESHOLD.NAME: High total docs in first queue (Portal_Content)

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \Office Server Search Archival Plugin(Portal_Content)\Total docs in first queue
CHART.DATASOURCE: \Office Server Search Archival Plugin(Portal_Content)\Total docs in first queue

ANALYSIS.NAME: Idle Crawler Threads
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
This counter monitors the number of threads the crawler is using. This analysis looks at the number of idle crawling threads. If the number of idle threads is too low, it's likely that too many content sources are being crawled at once.
For more on understanding the crawler counters and performance, please read the following: Creating crawl schedules and starvation - How to detect it and minimize it

ANALYSIS.NAME: Threads Accessing Network
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
This counter examines the number of crawler threads accessing the network. The analysis checks to see if the percentage of crawling threads accessing the network is too high. If the number is too high, then the crawler is network bound, or a "hungry host" is being crawled. This potentially means that your crawl is being slowed down. There are several types of content sources that can cause slow downs. For more specific information on host types, read the article linked below. You can distinguish the difference between actually waiting on the network versus filtering the document by looking at a combination of CPU usage and Network usage counters. If this number is consistently high then you are either network bound or you are bound by a "hungry" host. If you are not meeting your crawl freshness goals, you can either change your crawl schedules to minimize overlapping crawls or look the remote repositories you are crawling to optimize them for more throughput.

For more on understanding the crawler counters and performance, please read the following: Creating crawl schedules and starvation - How to detect it and minimize it

DATASOURCE.NAME: \Office Server Search Gatherer\Filtering Threads to Network Threads Ratio Percentage
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \Office Server Search Gatherer\Filtering Threads to Network Threads Ratio Percentage

THRESHOLD.NAME: The percentage of crawling threads accessing the network is over 75 percent

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \Office Server Search Gatherer\Filtering Threads to Network Threads Ratio Percentage
CHART.DATASOURCE: \Office Server Search Gatherer\Filtering Threads to Network Threads Ratio Percentage

ANALYSIS.NAME: Threads in Plug-ins
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
This counter examines the number of crawler threads inside of plug ins. When threads are in plug-ins, they're creating the index and property store. This analysis checks to see if the percentage of crawling threads in plug-ins is too high. If the percentage is high, then the crawler is likely SQL bound. Check the archival plug in values again.

For more on understanding the crawler counters and performance, please read the following: Creating crawl schedules and starvation - How to detect it and minimize it

DATASOURCE.NAME: \Office Server Search Gatherer\Plugin Threads to Filtering Threads Ratio Percentage
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \Office Server Search Gatherer\Plugin Threads to Filtering Threads Ratio Percentage
